summary: the etiology of diarrhea in neonatal foals is complex and involves infectious agents, management, and facilities, as well as nutritional, environmental, and physiological conditions. some studies of diarrhea in neonatal foals have focused on only one pathogen [2, 8–11] although it is usually caused by diverse combinations of enteric infections. a cross-sectional study was carried out at 15 horse farms (50–150 horses per farm) all foals with diarrhea identified at each farm were included in the study. an average of 7.5 foals per farm was used. the 116 foals were divided into diarrheic and nondiarrheic groups. they were then subdivided into three groups according to age. GI (0–30 days of age); GII (31–60 days); and GIII (61–90 days). aliquots of fecal samples were kept frozen (80°C) in the laboratory. for the culturing of Escherichia coli, fecal material was plated on defibrinated sheep blood agar and MacConkey agar and evaluated at 24, 48, and 72 hours. each broth culture was plated in xylose-lysine-deoxycholate agar and in bismuth sulfite agar. Suspected Salmonella sp. colonies were inoculated in triple sugar iron and lysine iron agar. a commercial agglutination test using polyvalent anti-Salmonella serum and serotype identification were also carried out. d with restriction endonucleases EcoRI, EcoT22I, and HindIII. plasmid samples were separated by electrophoresis and examined under UV light. foals have low levels of sodium, potassium, and calcium due to electrolyte loss caused by the diarrhea. etiology of infectious diarrhea in neonatal foals complex [3–5] four of 18 (22%) C. perfringens isolates were positive for the beta-2 toxin gene (cpb2), although only one cpb2+ was isolated from a diarrheic animal. the importance of beta-2 toxin in foals remains controversial. Salmonella Typhimurium appears to be the most commonly reported pathogenic serotype in equines of different ages. in the current study, Salmonella Infantis, Typhimurium, and Saintpaul were the most prevalent serotypes recovered from the diarrheic and nondiarrheic foals. this result is not surprising because this organism is part of the normal enteric microflora of livestock. fimbriae and LT, STa, and STb enterotoxins among the E. coli strains isolated from diarrheic and nondiarrheic foals indicates that this organism has little influence on enteric infections in foals. papC gene was detected in four diarrheic and in two nondiarrheic foals up to 90 days of age. ag43 expression has been implicated in chronic urinary tract infections in humans. this study is the first to report identification of the ag43 gene among E. coli strains isolated from diarrheic and nondiarrheic foals. none of 32 E. coli strains expressed verocytotoxins (vt1 and vt2) or eae. the vapA 85-kb type I and 87-kb type I plasmids are most frequently present in virulent R. equi strains in foals from Brazil. this is the first report of detection of VapA 85-kb type I and 87-kb type I strains in diarrheic foals in south America. lawsonia intracellularis was not detected by nested PCR in any of the fecal samples from foals. it was probably not detected because only foals up to 90 days of age were analyzed. coronaviruses are infectious viruses that affect a wide range of domestic animals, wildlife species, and humans. C. parvum has been identified at a high frequency (25%) in diarrheic foals in Trinidad. a significantly higher frequency has been detected in nondiarrheic animals. a low prevalence of S. westeri has been described in the united kingdom. the higher frequencies of S. westeri and Strongylus across the studied farms reflect the inadequacy of deworming control programs. a large number of enteric pathogens of bacterial, viral, and parasitic origins have been identified in diarrheic and nondiarrheic foals. a high mortality rate was observed among the Salmonella-positive diarrheic foals, regardless of the serotype or other pathogens present. a large number of enteric pathogens of bacterial, viral, and parasitic origins have been identified in diarrheic and nondiarrheic foals. a high mortality rate was observed among the Salmonella-positive diarrheic foals, regardless of the serotype. Salmonella spp. was the most prevalent pathogen associated with mortality among the diarrheic and nondiarrheic foals sampled. a wide variety of enteric pathogens in foals were identified in this study. the detection of different serotypes of Salmonella, toxigenic Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium difficile strains highlights a public health concern. practitioners should be careful when handling fecal material from foals because these organisms are recognized as human pathogens through fecal contamination of food and water.
